title: Chinese Government pledges a grant for the Upgrade of the Lao-China Friendship Hospital
description: On April 10, 2018, the Chinese Government and the Government of Laos signed an agreement for a feasibility study on China's aid for the Upgrade of the Lao-China Friendship Hospital (also known as Luang Prabang Provincial Hospital). The project explored by the feasibility study would see the addition of a surgery and cardiovascular building, an outpatient and emergency department, an inpatient department, additional intensive-care unit beds, a surgery operation room, a DSA area, a telehealth center, and a classroom for training over a total land area of 74,677 square meters and on a new construction area of 5,680 square meters. After the project, the Lao-China Friendship Hospital was expected to become the main hospital of northern Laos and the teaching hospital of Luang Prabang provincial medical school.  The project was then mentioned in a five-year action plan signed on April 30, 2019, but it does not appear to have been committed at this time.  On March 30, 2021, a professional inspection nine-person team from China Railway No. 2 Group Co., Ltd. Kunming Research Design Institute and Kunming Construction Consulting Management Co., Ltd. arrived in Laos to negotiate the project plan and sign an implementation agreement with Laos. By this time, the Chinese Government had committed grant financing for the project, as well as three years of technical assistance and medical training for Laotian medical staff in China.  On January 13, 2023, the 14th Bureau of China Power Construction Hydropower Co., Ltd.  held a groundbreaking ceremony for the project, which is currently under implementation.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 中国援老挝琅勃拉邦医院升级改造项目.2. The Commitment date is unclear; based on the feasibility study it does not appear that a full grant agreement was signed until at least 2021 (notice how the implementation agreement had not been signed by then).
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government pledges a grant for the Upgrade of the Lao-China Friendship Hospital

# Description
On April 10, 2018, the Chinese Government and the Government of Laos signed an agreement for a feasibility study on China's aid for the Upgrade of the Lao-China Friendship Hospital (also known as Luang Prabang Provincial Hospital). The project explored by the feasibility study would see the addition of a surgery and cardiovascular building, an outpatient and emergency department, an inpatient department, additional intensive-care unit beds, a surgery operation room, a DSA area, a telehealth center, and a classroom for training over a total land area of 74,677 square meters and on a new construction area of 5,680 square meters. After the project, the Lao-China Friendship Hospital was expected to become the main hospital of northern Laos and the teaching hospital of Luang Prabang provincial medical school.  The project was then mentioned in a five-year action plan signed on April 30, 2019, but it does not appear to have been committed at this time.  On March 30, 2021, a professional inspection nine-person team from China Railway No. 2 Group Co., Ltd. Kunming Research Design Institute and Kunming Construction Consulting Management Co., Ltd. arrived in Laos to negotiate the project plan and sign an implementation agreement with Laos. By this time, the Chinese Government had committed grant financing for the project, as well as three years of technical assistance and medical training for Laotian medical staff in China.  On January 13, 2023, the 14th Bureau of China Power Construction Hydropower Co., Ltd.  held a groundbreaking ceremony for the project, which is currently under implementation.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare infrastructure and medical training without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Hospital upgrade project including new medical facilities, training center, and technical assistance for medical staff

title: Chinese Government donates 300,000 Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $5.4 million in February 2021
description: On February 8, 2021, The Chinese Government delivered 300,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Laos. Then, on March 2, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 500,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines and the People’s Liberation Army (PLA) of China delivered 300,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Laos. Several weeks later, on March 31, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 800,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos. Approximately one month later, on April 26, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 300,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos. Then, on June 14, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 500,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos.   On August 7, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 1 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos. Two weeks later, on August 23, 2021, the People’s Liberation Army of China (PLA) donated 400,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Lao People's Army. The shipment was carried by PLA Air Force's Y-20 transport aircraft and arrived at Wattay International Airport in the capital city of Vientiane. Defense attache of the Chinese embassy in Laos Li Bing and Laotian Deputy Minister of National Defense Vongkham Phommakone attended the handover ceremony held on the arrival of the vaccines. Then, on October 13, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 1 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos.   Approximately one month later, on November 17, 2021, the Red Cross Society of China delivered an additional 100,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Lao Red Cross Society. One week later, on November 24, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 1.9 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses and medical supplies — including protective personal equipment — to the Laotian Ministry of Health. Then, on January 25, 2022, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 1.5 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos. Approximately one month later, on February 17, 2022, the Yunnan Provincial Government of China delivered an 423,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses and other medical supplies to the Laotian Ministry of Health. The February 17, 2022 batch of vaccine doses was handed over by the Deputy Head of Yunnan Province’s Commerce Department to officials from Luang Namtha Province, while officials from Bokeo and Luang Prabang provinces took delivery at the Boten International Checkpoint.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the February 2021 donation as $5.4 million.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates 300,000 Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $5.4 million in February 2021

# Description
On February 8, 2021, The Chinese Government delivered 300,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Laos. Then, on March 2, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered 500,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines and the People’s Liberation Army (PLA) of China delivered 300,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Laos. Several weeks later, on March 31, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 800,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos. Approximately one month later, on April 26, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 300,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos. Then, on June 14, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 500,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos.   On August 7, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 1 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos. Two weeks later, on August 23, 2021, the People’s Liberation Army of China (PLA) donated 400,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Lao People's Army. The shipment was carried by PLA Air Force's Y-20 transport aircraft and arrived at Wattay International Airport in the capital city of Vientiane. Defense attache of the Chinese embassy in Laos Li Bing and Laotian Deputy Minister of National Defense Vongkham Phommakone attended the handover ceremony held on the arrival of the vaccines. Then, on October 13, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 1 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos.   Approximately one month later, on November 17, 2021, the Red Cross Society of China delivered an additional 100,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Lao Red Cross Society. One week later, on November 24, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 1.9 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses and medical supplies — including protective personal equipment — to the Laotian Ministry of Health. Then, on January 25, 2022, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 1.5 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos. Approximately one month later, on February 17, 2022, the Yunnan Provincial Government of China delivered an 423,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses and other medical supplies to the Laotian Ministry of Health. The February 17, 2022 batch of vaccine doses was handed over by the Deputy Head of Yunnan Province’s Commerce Department to officials from Luang Namtha Province, while officials from Bokeo and Luang Prabang provinces took delivery at the Boten International Checkpoint.
justification: Project involves donation of vaccines and medical supplies, which is unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Multiple shipments of Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccines and medical supplies to Laos, categorized under health sector

title: Chinese Government sends medical expert team to Laos to fight against COVID-19 pandemic in May 2021
description: On May 4th, 2021, the anti-pandemic medical expert team sent by the Chinese government arrived at Vientiane International Airport. Chinese ambassador Jiang Zaidong and Laos Deputy Prime Minister Ji Qiao greeted the team. The team will aid Laos in various areas of anti-pandemic tasks.   Ji Qiao appreciated the aid from the Chinese government and express willingness to cooperate with China in public health and other related aspects.   On May 18th, 2021, the Chinese anti-pandemic medical expert team in Laos held a work summary meeting with the Laos Ministry of Health. Lao Minister of Health Ben Fung awarded honorary certificates to the members of the expert group to recognize and thank them for their outstanding contributions to Laos' public health. The expert team left Laos and returned to China on the same day in the afternoon.
staff_comments: 1.) The Chinese project title is 中国政府派遣医疗专家组前往老挝协助抗击新冠肺炎大流行.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government sends medical expert team to Laos to fight against COVID-19 pandemic in May 2021

# Description
On May 4th, 2021, the anti-pandemic medical expert team sent by the Chinese government arrived at Vientiane International Airport. Chinese ambassador Jiang Zaidong and Laos Deputy Prime Minister Ji Qiao greeted the team. The team will aid Laos in various areas of anti-pandemic tasks.   Ji Qiao appreciated the aid from the Chinese government and express willingness to cooperate with China in public health and other related aspects.   On May 18th, 2021, the Chinese anti-pandemic medical expert team in Laos held a work summary meeting with the Laos Ministry of Health. Lao Minister of Health Ben Fung awarded honorary certificates to the members of the expert group to recognize and thank them for their outstanding contributions to Laos' public health. The expert team left Laos and returned to China on the same day in the afternoon.
justification: Project focuses on public health assistance without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical expert team, COVID-19 pandemic response, public health cooperation

title: Chinese Government aids Laos with anti-pandemic prevention materials in May 2021
description: On May 10th, 2021,  anti-pandemic prevention materials assist by the Chinese government to Laos were delivered by a chartered flight to Wattay International Airport in Vientiane. Chinese ambassador Jiang Zaidong handed it over to Ji Qiao, Laos deputy prime minister of the government.  This particular batch includes more than 20 items of materials, including ventilators, automatic nucleic acid extraction instruments, medical masks, N95 masks, mobile hospital beds, automatic autoclaves, nucleic acid extraction or purification reagents, and nucleic acid detection kits.  Laos appreciates China's aid during this challenging era and believes these materials will provide strong support and guarantee for Laos to win the battle of COVID-19 pandemic prevention and control.
staff_comments: 1.) The Chinese project title is 中国政府援助老挝抗击新冠肺炎物资.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government aids Laos with anti-pandemic prevention materials in May 2021

# Description
On May 10th, 2021,  anti-pandemic prevention materials assist by the Chinese government to Laos were delivered by a chartered flight to Wattay International Airport in Vientiane. Chinese ambassador Jiang Zaidong handed it over to Ji Qiao, Laos deputy prime minister of the government.  This particular batch includes more than 20 items of materials, including ventilators, automatic nucleic acid extraction instruments, medical masks, N95 masks, mobile hospital beds, automatic autoclaves, nucleic acid extraction or purification reagents, and nucleic acid detection kits.  Laos appreciates China's aid during this challenging era and believes these materials will provide strong support and guarantee for Laos to win the battle of COVID-19 pandemic prevention and control.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare and pandemic prevention without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Delivery of medical equipment and supplies including ventilators, masks, and testing equipment for COVID-19 response

On August 7, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 1 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos. Two weeks later, on August 23, 2021, the People’s Liberation Army of China (PLA) donated 400,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Lao People's Army. The shipment was carried by PLA Air Force's Y-20 transport aircraft and arrived at Wattay International Airport in the capital city of Vientiane. Defense attache of the Chinese embassy in Laos Li Bing and Laotian Deputy Minister of National Defense Vongkham Phommakone attended the handover ceremony held on the arrival of the vaccines. Then, on October 13, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 1 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos.   Approximately one month later, on November 17, 2021, the Red Cross Society of China delivered an additional 100,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Lao Red Cross Society. One week later, on November 24, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 1.9 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses and medical supplies — including protective personal equipment — to the Laotian Ministry of Health. Then, on January 25, 2022, the Chinese Government delivered an additional 1.5 million donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Laos. Approximately one month later, on February 17, 2022, the Yunnan Provincial Government of China delivered an 423,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses and other medical supplies to the Laotian Ministry of Health. The February 17, 2022 batch of vaccine doses was handed over by the Deputy Head of Yunnan Province’s Commerce Department to officials from Luang Namtha Province, while officials from Bokeo and Luang Prabang provinces took delivery at the Boten International Checkpoint.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the June 2021 donation as $9 million.
